1110214600119586816.text:
Every single zero knowledge proof in the code base is either:

1115016878190145536.text: Anyway, the point here is that when Heartbleed came along, it wasn’t just a bug in “some library that people in the government happened to use.” It was a flaw in software that the DoD had made a special exception for, so they could use extensively.

1115014870754312192.text: (The people who run the USG’s Cryptographic Module Validation Program seem to hate this and have been trying to take this exception way for years. As much as I hate FIPS, moving back to proprietary junk seems worse.)

1115013260783255558.text: To the best of my knowledge, OpenSSL is (still, and definitely for a long time) the only cryptographic product that got this special treatment. You could use the source without recertifying every binary. This was huge for the DoD, so it got used a lot.

1115012871535116290.text: Some very bright bureaucratic warriors inside the DoD saw the value of certifying a piece of open source software, and realized this could save the government a ton of money. So they pushed hard and got the first “source code certification” for the OpenSSL FIPS module.

1115012396056236032.text: More critically, even though FIPS validation covers source code, the validation certificate itself did not. You only got to certify the binary. And only for specific architectures. This changed with OpenSSL.

1115012164023091205.text: Any cryptography software used for sensitive-but-unclassified data protection in USG needs to have FIPS certification. This means an expensive validation that was, for a long time, pretty much inaccessible to open source developers.

1115011744496267264.text: I guess since we’re talking about OpenSSL and the US government, it’s worth explaining something unique and special about that software that also makes its correct operation particularly important to US national security.

1115009579195273217.text: Anyone who tells you ‘an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure’ obviously never tried to convince people to invest in prevention. Attacks matter. Security advances one massive, public, messy vulnerability at a time.

1115009149367140352.text:
Anyway, within a few weeks of Heartbleed the Linux Foundation had established the Core Infrastructure Initiative and poured millions into OpenSSL and other projects. 

The OpenBSD people tore into the code and livetweeted it at @ValhallaSSL.

1115007908184514561.text: The money seemed so tiny compared to the risk companies and government was exposed to. 1115005084725862400.text: My efforts accomplished absolutely nothing, but I learned later than someone in the Obama administration ran it by their superiors. Which made them look smart in the wake of Heartbleed.

1111262814256201734.text:
I’ve worked with Huawei engineers. They were super nice and I found the entire organization to be impressive and earnest.

But, as the Snowden documents showed, it’s never good policy to blindly trust a foreign equipment manufacturer if you don’t trust their government. /Fin

1111262334901719041.text: Last point: I am not saying that Huawei is malicious. I am only saying that dishonest behavior by Huawei is *within the threat model the UK is applying*, and that the partnership and review systems are trying to rule out. 11/

1111261730116505600.text: Whether you believe this or not, this report shows that Huawei-UK is nowhere near even having the capability to give this a shot. 10/

1111261165143969798.text: Personally I think this is an impossible problem, even in the best case. Our best software security techniques are barely sufficient to stop accidental vulnerabilities being introduced by honest developers. They can’t possibly work against a manufacturer acting with malice. 9/

1111260216962805760.text: While this is potentially true of other vendors, particularly those that are just spinning up and have immature codebases, those vendors aren’t trying to achieve the unique feat that the UK-Huawei partnership is: namely make a not-fully-trusted partner into a trusted one. 8/

1111259815689502722.text: Even if Huawei solves that problem (and they’ve been trying for some time apparently), the codebase is apparently a mess. It contains a bunch of insecure dependencies, each of which brings in a stack of known vulnerabilities. 7/

1111259124346642432.text: This problem of “reproducible builds” is a big annoying one across our industry. The binaries running on the devices have to be the same as the ones that get built from code that’s been reviewed, or you’re just wasting people’s time. 6/

1111258663434498048.text: There are several problems here, but they all amount to “our reviews are worthless.” The biggest one is that currently, the UK govt can’t even verify that the code running in Huawei equipment is the same code they were given to review. 5/

1111258352414326785.text: What this report says is *not* that Huawei is uniquely bad. And *not* that there’s anything malicious in the software. But rather, that the current condition of Huawei SW development makes this external review layer non-functional. 4/

1111258019122286592.text: What the UK appears to have been attempting is to split this difference. Buy Huawei equipment, but put an independent layer of UK cybersecurity analysis on top — to ensure that they can obtain the financial benefits while also mitigating security concerns. 3/

1106563516381696000.text: Also, some folks object to my colorful analogies. So here’s the same statement expressed in technical language: “Scytl used a proof that relies on a Common Reference String and didn’t realize this, so they generated the CRS at Proving time.”

1106534400144166913.text: It is very hard to convey how bad this looks from an expert perspective. It’s like meeting a “surgeon” who doesn’t realize that a scalpel should be sterilized between patients; and when you point this out, they try to explain scalpel-reuse as “standard”.

1106533726090117121.text: They’re also trying to use some kind of “we knew about this serious bug and failed to fix it” defense, which is frankly even worse than the alternative. You knew, and you left a devastating flaw in? And you should be trusted, how?

1106533278583062528.text: Scytl and @swisspost are trying to write this off as some sort of arcane argument about “how to generate parameters”, when the misunderstanding here is much deeper and more fundamental. It’s like they’ve been using the shaft of the hammer to pound down nails.

1106532747684794373.text: From an API perspective, the parameters should be an *input* to the Prove routine. Scytl didn’t realize this. They decided to put the Setup routine inside the Prove routine, which is the cryptographic equivalent of trying to walk through a glass door.

1106532153473581057.text: The BG mix proof in their system has a “setup” phase in which the parameters for the proof are chosen. That means the parameters need to be chosen by a trusted party or a verifiable process, not chosen during the proving routine (as Scytl currently does.)

1106531685393412100.text: Scytl, the company that developed the broken @swisspost voting system, put out a misleading statement about what the problem in their system is. I think it’s worth unpacking.pic.twitter.com/wxUqmSlinD

1106319427178500096.text: Oh wow that feels better now.

1106319378725986304.text: Oh hell. Too late I just thought of the nerd metaphor this whole thread was crying out for: using (ZK) proving tech is like taking a shortcut through Moria. It’s faster than going over the mountain, but sometimes you have to fight the Balrog.

1106317328160038913.text: We’ve just replaced one totally intractable problem: building high assurance security software, with one really-really-hard problem: building high-assurance crypto software. That’s huge progress, but nowhere near a fait accompli. /fin

1106316699240943616.text: This tweet thread is apropos of @SarahJamieLewis’s thread, in which she responds to a cryptographer who says ZK proofs solve all the problems in e-voting. They don’t — Sarah and her colleagues just showed that.https://twitter.com/sarahjamielewis/status/1106302115373170688?s=21 …

1106316160298115074.text: This is not to say we can’t do it. In fact, the deployed progress we’re seeing with proving tech and ZK is amazing! It’s just that we’re in early days. Nobody should mistake the ideal “what it could do” for the idea that we’ve solved secure software.

1106313107960487938.text: And particularly when there’s privacy involved (eg ZK for voting, ecash) it can be extremely hard to distinguish between a perfectly secure proof and a totally bogus one allowed by a subtle software flaw.

1106312600554536961.text: There’s only one problem with this vision, which underlies a bunch of voting technology and some blockchain tech (CT, Monero, Zcash): proving technology is freakishly complicated and hard to get right.

1106312144767860736.text: This is a great thing, in the sense that the only code we have to look at (from a soundness perspective) is the verification code for the ZK proof. So that’s theoretically orders of magnitude less code.

1106311885656375306.text: (Zero knowledge) proofs can do the same thing. In principle they could let us build wads of relatively crummy code that can afford to be crummy, because the proofs ensure that all calculations were done correctly.

1106311501755891712.text: We don’t know how to build giant messaging infrastructure that are secure, so we use encryption to make sure that all we have to secure is the encryption code. The rest of the system can be crap.

1106311212952895488.text: Verifiable computation (including zero knowledge) is one of those technologies, like encryption, that makes the most sense when you describe it as a way to reduce the size of the trusted computing base.

1105467993671135232.text:
The very worst thing we could do as cryptographers is convince people to move critical societal functions into opaque experimental-quality cryptographic systems they can’t understand or even argue with.

And then implement those systems incorrectly.

1105457705244942336.text: Yes. I absolutely did say this. I expected to see flaws in the crypto. I expected RNG flaws. I did not expect to see a system using a sophisticated cryptographic primitive at a fundamental place, and yet failing to understand the security of Pedersen.

1105434865158275072.text: @SarahJamieLewis has been pointing the poor code quality out from the day she started looking at the code a few weeks ago. That in just that short time, she and @VTeagueAus and Olivier were able to complete break the system — not a coincidence.

1105434030965751809.text: This is not a question of substituting an “==“ for an “=“. There are relatively few bugs that can (1) totally compromise an e2e verifiable election *and* (2) demonstrate that the designers don’t understand the cryptographic tools they’re working with. This bug does both.

1105433244823154688.text: The @swisspost folks are going to write this off as a “bug” and a successful result of their bug bounty program. But don’t let that fool you. This is the equivalent of installing the shock absorbers backwards when you’re building a nuclear plant on top of the San Andreas fault.

1105432226815201280.text: Even worse, this stolen election would be “end to end verifiable” thanks to the appearance of valid ZK proofs. Good luck disputing “math”.

1105431730159263744.text: In the extreme case (which takes a few other conditions, like a flaw elsewhere in the JavaScript client) this could allow a single mix server to replace every ballot it sees with a new ballot. Such an attack would be hard to detect.

1105431044004761600.text: The designers of the @swisspost system somehow did not realize this. They instead generated those critical parameters fresh with each ZK proof the system makes. This undermines the soundness of the proof system.

1105430733194178560.text: What @VTeagueAus, @SarahJamieLewis and Olivier noticed was that the BG proof uses a Pedersen commitment scheme. Most people know that Pedersen commitments rely on a set of “bases” that have to be generated in a trustworthy way: you can’t know a relationship between them.

1105430015154577408.text: The @swisspost system deals with this by using a zero-knowledge proof that the shuffle was correct, and no votes were replaced. Unfortunately they got the implementation of this (Bayer-Groth) proof badly wrong.

1105429520813903874.text: This mix/shuffle step poses a problem. Because the shuffled ballots are re-encrypted in an unrecognizable form, a malicious server could (hypothetically) replace all of the real ballots with invented ones that elect any candidate of their choosing.

1105429232581255173.text: Specifically, each voter sends their ballots in to a server in an encrypted form. The server later decrypts and tallies them. In between these two stages, to preserve privacy, a series of servers “mixes” the votes by re-encrypting and shuffling them.

1105428898727297024.text: The problem occurs because the voting system implements a series of sophisticated cryptographic zero-knowledge proofs, in order to keep votes encrypted and untraceable while also preserving election integrity. At a critical place, one of the proofs is flawed.

1105428008075227137.text: So @SarahJamieLewis, @VTeagueAus and Olivier Periera have found a critical vulnerability in the @swisspost cryptographic voting system. In the worst case, it allows for massive and centralized election fraud. https://people.eng.unimelb.edu.au/vjteague/SwissVote …

1097616492844204032.text: What I’m trying to get across here is that this is *not* exactly like a bad online voting system, where the attacker maybe has to tamper with thousands of clients. If there are bugs in these proofs, the attacker could potentially do a huge amount of damage. 13/

1097615077639929856.text: The wonderful, horrible thing about zero knowledge proofs is that when they work, they’re amazing. When they fail, they can fail *undetectably*. Believe me, I have stories. 12/http://fortune.com/2019/02/05/zcash-vulnerability-cryptocurrency/ …

1097614468727664641.text:
All of these bad things are kept at bay with one of my favorite tools: zero knowledge proofs.

A ZKP makes sure you can’t vote 10,000 times. A ZKP makes sure that the shuffler (mix) doesn’t just throw away and replace all the ballots. (Actually this is a MESS of proofs.) 11/

1097613571087839237.text: The beauty of this system is that nobody can see what’s in the ballots. So I could try to vote twice. Or much more worryingly, the shuffle step could just *replace* all the ballots with new ones that elect, say, a Swiss cryptographer to office. 10/

1097613076541726720.text:
When you vote, your ballot is encrypted. The magic of this system is that it can do four things:

1. Verify your ballot is legit. 
2. Strip away your ID, and cryptographically shuffle ballots.
3. Add the ballots up *without decrypting them*.
4. Decrypt the final tallies. 9/
